reviews.text:
This museum is connected to the University - super crowded with students! Our museum guide was very knowledgeable & passionate (I'm told he's a lecturer at the University) about the cultural history of Ethiopia.

Our visit to this museum went smoothly. Our guesthouse host made everything seems seamless!! If you're staying at a guesthouse, take advantage of the service - !!

Provides a rich history and culture of Ethiopia. Itwas a discovery for me to know which community a coffee pot is from by the shape of it. The student guide who accompanied us was very nice in describing the different sections and items if the museum.

The museum itself was great. 100birr per person. However the museum is located within the university, which would have been fine if the guard at the gates didn’t insist on keeping my partner’s ID. Given all we had given him was a driver’s licence. But if we hadn’t brought that along, we would have had to give him a passport. This guard just sits at the gate, not even slightly secure behind a counter, there was no technology to photocopy the ID and he insisted on hanging onto it. I was incredibly unhappy with that and had left a sour taste as we headed in. What was worse was when we decided to let him keep it, we came across a couple foreigners who told us they had taken a cab straight into the University and were not asked to present any ID let alone had to leave it with someone who had no way of securing it. We went back to the guard and demanded our ID back with those foreigners, and he still wouldn’t give it back to us. So, pro tip, if you want to go in, go with a cab, DO NOT walk in unless if you want to risk having your passport taken from you and just left lying around on a chair next to him where anyone could have just taken like we had seen most foreign IDs were when we left.

I would not support the museum for this reason and I urge the university to change their policy. Photocopy the ID if you have to, but foreigners should not be handing in their passport just to enter the university.
Good collection of cultural artifacts. The displays could be better organized and the absence of a good gift shop is a missed opportunity. Worth a visit.
Kind of disappointing but interesting.

Best place to visit . It is found inside Addis Ababa university , College of natural and computational science compound .
Several wild animals are found reserved ( killed and dried ) 
It has entrance fee 
For regular students (AAU students ) and children - 5 birr
For adult Ethiopians - 15 birr
For foreigners - 100 birr 
If you want to record and take a picture you have to pay another fee .
But all the payments are totally worth it .
I RECOMMEND YOU TO VISIT THIS PLACE .
Museum was closed despite that it's supposed to be opened.  No explanations.  Don't bother going.
It is consist of historical and inspire objects.
Easy to miss. Still worth a walk through for the insect and mammal collections, modest though they are. Gives a sense of the biological  diversity of the country.

It's a modest and concise museum, easily doable under 1hr. Powerful and thought-provoking, the museum deals with the atrocities conducted under the communist Mengistu regime that ruled Ethiopia from 1974 to the early 90s. The museum is best enjoyed with one of the friendly guides at the front desk. They'll guide you free of charge, and our guide was himself a survivor of the political violence. The museum is not for the faint-hearted and probably not appropriate for very young children. If you get a chance, definitely pay it a visit.

A museum to visit for those who are interested in knowing the recent past of Ethiopia. Helpful to discover the history of this regime still mostly unknown in Europe. Free entrance but possible to leave a donation.

This museum is a must if one wants to learn about Ethiopia's recent past. The Derg regime is only 30-40 years away. The museum is small, but very effective in conveying the terror which the Ethiopian people faced daily during Mengistu Hailemariam. Be prepared for strong exhibitions towards the end of the tour (human remains).

It is small, but one must visit. Speak to locals there who lived thru this regime, and try to learn 'both sides' as there are many different opinions. The museum is free (donation box at end if desired). Many of the exhibits are not in English, so good to go with a translator or a guide. (There are many guides there who lived through this period & will share stories on this beyond horrific time.) 
NOTE -There is a lot more to be learned about this period and about this museum then what you see and learn there physically. Read. Try to speak to local people, especially the younger generations and their opinion and what is going on with the current government today.

Peek into ET history during the dreg regime Somber place An eye opener into past atrocities Lives lost on exhibit Modest plc Nothing fancy Too many people lost their lives during this time No entry fee Donations only
Nice but very simple. Good tour with a deacon!
Nice looking cathedral.

Although it's clearly free for people to walk the grounds of this church, I was approached and escorted to a ticket office by a staff member. The office asked for 200birr! I told them I didn't want to go inside the cathedral and they said I still had to pay or I had to leave. The place had dozens of people walking the grounds who I highly doubt paid 200birr. Still I left the grounds. Even after exiting I was reprimanded by a guard for standing on the street near the cathedral. I'm used to getting foreigner prices,  but this is ridiculous.
Must visit in Addis. Better with guide for more interesting stories
Amazing design and painted windows, great hospitality
Impressive building serving as the headquarters for the African Union economic commission.
Well secured and amazing conference halls.
Very nice
A well organized and large conference space.

This place is now called African Union headquarters if am not wrong. I was here for a conference, the buildings are amazing. This is where most African country heads meet. Amazing location within Addis Ababa and well designed.
The monument is in horrible condition. Be CAREFUL FOR PICK POCKETS. They all hang out there and target tourists.
The idea is nice, but the dreadlocks are ok!
The Statue which is located near the old train station consists the lion and 3 former kings  and  a queen. The statues placed here are really  beautiful and catches attention. I was impressed.
Just a statue, nothing special
Too small, not powerful enough
The monument is in horrible condition. Be CAREFUL FOR PICK POCKETS. They all hang out there and target tourists.
The idea is nice, but the dreadlocks are ok!
The Statue which is located near the old train station consists the lion and 3 former kings  and  a queen. The statues placed here are really  beautiful and catches attention. I was impressed.
Just a statue, nothing special
Too small, not powerful enough
u wan sum? jk lmao ur too poor

Don't approach the Palace, don't look at it, don't walk on the same side of the street as it, don't take pictures of it, don't talk to it, try not to smell the flowers near it - forget it's existence. As far as the military would have you believe - there's nothing there so move along please.
Very Beautifule....
This a beauty the king reign here
You can watch three government historical things
Delicious pizza 🍕 and good tasting pasta. The place is nice and cozy with an antique charm.
I love this place in Ethiopia. Very good food. Really good
An isolated and beautiful property which is slightly worn out but still carries a charm. They serve delicious Italian inspired food in Ethiopian Style. Do eat the Teff bread.

It was a good place, But my last experience (October) wasn't pleasant! 
We didn't like the food, moreover the service was bad and slow.
The menu is huge and Ethiopia is the right place for vegan and veggie dishes. Gluten free snacks are also available. The food is good, I wouldn't say exceptional. The service is always great!
Nice place to check mails have a drink or quick lunch. Closes at 9pm. Nice homemade cakes. Friendly staff
Good for a quick food and chit chat
Had the best special tea. Looks like had honey ginger lime.
A good place to have a coffee in kazanchis.
I enjoyed the food here and it was a convenient place to walk to from the Elilly hotel for a coffee and a brownie. They also have free WiFi.
Great pizza here!
Sehr gute Pizza,Service sehr gut
One of the best Indian restaurant in Addis. Best service, excellent food,
It’s the oldest Indian restaurant with good food and average service standards.

I dont ever give 5 star ratings but on the rare occasions I do its a definite must try if I give it a 5 star. Sangam is more than a restaurant to me its apart of my family I have been going to this establishment since I was 8 years old and is home to my fondest memories and the best meals I have ever had and in all these years the food has not once changed in flavor or consistency I would say this is a true measure of restaurant quality as it is harder to be good and stay good for 22 years... The staff are polite and treat you like a VIP and this is by far my favorite restaurant in Ethiopia
1st time after they moved from Bole street, and still the best indian restaurant in Addis. price and staff service remains the same. very warm staffs. you will get no disappointment from this place.

Just like Indian cuisine 
Not authentic 
Atmosphere  is good 
With average taste
